My careless intern leaked half my RSA key, but the encrypted flag (3033694319538773911600504261592923832497870057600846541954203570985907799618424123415265148941854052060421620813318284178911801909222114568417104666775915) is still safe... right?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=4010866182668830397846149062150024499353425486515635247806294784382646275333447317277903405575794554137083122349391341947243735659767368364294395559472187, e=1079179772539300562299800900933638562536183277253726128376128673800776601861119812707752360120052670996022933178916622681516256304547405277855902276497765, partial_p=9593075870834903403

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{6jw1olxg}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 3033694319538773911600504261592923832497870057600846541954203570985907799618424123415265148941854052060421620813318284178911801909222114568417104666775915
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=4010866182668830397846149062150024499353425486515635247806294784382646275333447317277903405575794554137083122349391341947243735659767368364294395559472187, e=1079179772539300562299800900933638562536183277253726128376128673800776601861119812707752360120052670996022933178916622681516256304547405277855902276497765, partial_p=9593075870834903403
extra_info: p=60216713196513865959025855798845771757809058243152247964799819046504861190579, q=66607192086017607443093035862052137880324404847724318661249995329174582558553, Ï†(n)=4010866182668830397846149062150024499353425486515635247806294784382646275333320493372620874102392435245422224439753208484152859093141318549918716115723056
